importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the latest indictment filed by the U.S. Justice Department against Smartmatic, marking a pivotal development in its legal and reputational standing.
The year when the alleged bribe to a Philippine election official occurred, forming the basis of the foreign bribery charges.
The year when Smartmatic filed defamation lawsuits against pro-Trump figures and media outlets alleging spread of false election-related claims.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which Smartmatic's defamation lawsuits against pro-Trump figures were filed and actively pursued, intersecting with the recent foreign bribery indictment.

keyTakeAways: The U.S. Justice Department filed foreign bribery charges against Smartmatic, alleging a $1 million bribe to a top Philippine election official in 2016 to secure contracts.
The charges do not allege voter fraud or election rigging in the U.S. or abroad, but focus solely on illegal payments in the Philippines.
Smartmatic is suing Fox News, Jeanine Pirro, Rudy Giuliani, and Mike Lindell for defamation over false claims about its 2020 election technology.
The indictment may undermine Smartmatic’s argument that its reputation has been solely damaged by pro-Trump misinformation, weakening its defamation claims.
Smartmatic denies wrongdoing, claims the case is politically motivated and influenced by powerful interests, and says it cooperated fully with the government.
The company’s voting systems are only used in Los Angeles County, where local officials have stated the contracts were valid and compliant with strict terms.
The defamation lawsuits include settlements with Newsmax ($40 million) and One America News (undisclosed amount), with all defendants denying wrongdoing.
Pro-Trump figures are using the indictment to argue that Smartmatic’s practices undermine its credibility, potentially weakening damages claims in court.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. Justice Department filed foreign bribery charges against Smartmatic, alleging a $1 million bribe paid to a top Philippine election official in 2016 to secure contracts, though no allegations of election fraud are involved. This indictment, which does not relate to U.S. elections or the integrity of Los Angeles County’s voting systems, could undermine Smartmatic’s defamation lawsuits against pro-Trump figures such as Fox News, Jeanine Pirro, Rudy Giuliani, and Mike Lindell, who falsely claimed Smartmatic rigged the 2020 election. Smartmatic denies wrongdoing, claims political bias in the case, and argues the indictment undermines its ability to claim reputational damage solely from defamation. The defamation cases, which include settlements with Newsmax and One America News, may now face challenges as the bribery allegations cast doubt on whether the damage stemmed from false claims or from criminal conduct. Local election officials in Los Angeles County maintain that the contract with Smartmatic was valid and properly governed.
title: Smartmatic Indicted in Foreign Bribery Case, Possibly Endangering Its Lawsuits Against Fox News and Giuliani
